channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: French Comedian Stands Trial Over Comment Against Jewish Journalist
item.description: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala stood trial in criminal court on Wednesday over a comment he made lamenting that a prominent Jewish journalist did not die in “the gas chambers,” prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dystopian Reality of China’s Smog Captured in ‘Airpocalypse’ App
item.description: Airpocalypse, a sleek, color-coded app, provides weather conditions in Chinese cities, shows air quality measurements and, perhaps most important, “shares your excitement” on clear days and “feels your pain” on smoggy ones.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: A Beijing resident wore a mask against heavy air pollution near the China Central Television headquarters in November.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 1989 Cables Offer New Detail, and Questions, on Tiananmen
item.description: The release of Canadian diplomatic cables has cast new light on the military crackdown in Beijing, but one assertion in them — that top Chinese officials asked the Swiss ambassador about transferring large sums abroad — has been disputed.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Civilians wounded in the suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing being rushed to a hospital on June 4, 1989. Hundreds, possibly thousands, were killed.

item.title: Tsipras’s Debt Plan Sends Athens Stock Market Sliding
item.description: The Athens Stock Exchange fell more than 9% as the country’s prime minister said he would move quickly to renegotiate the country’s debt terms.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, third from left, the Greek prime minister, attended the first meeting of his new cabinet on Wednesday.

item.title: Hezbollah Kills 2 Israeli Soldiers Near Lebanon
item.description: The missile strike was the latest in a string of events along Israel’s northern frontiers that have raised the risk of a broader confrontation.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A wounded Israeli soldier was carried Wednesday after an antitank missile hit a convoy in a disputed area on the Lebanon border.

item.title: U.S. Suddenly Goes Quiet on Effort to Bolster Afghan Forces
item.description: The American-led coalition regularly shared details on how the money was being put to use, but as of this month the information is now considered classified.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers training in Kabul. United States officials now say that releasing information on military aid could endanger American and Afghan lives.

item.title: New Report Urges Western Governments to Reconsider Reliance on Biofuels
item.description: An environmental think tank says turning plant matter into liquid fuel or electricity is so inefficient that the approach is unlikely ever to supply a substantial fraction of global energy demand.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: A report says that biofuel production could use up tracts of land that could be devoted to helping feed the world’s population.

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: Lawmakers Approve Civil Unions for Gay or Heterosexual Couples
item.description: After nearly four years of legislative wrangling, legislators in socially conservative Chile approved civil unions on Wednesday for same-sex and unmarried heterosexual couples
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Court Rules for Rights Group
item.description: Russia’s Supreme Court on Thursday dismissed a government effort to shut down Memorial, the country’s oldest human rights advocacy group.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Police Bullets Killed a Hostage in Sydney Cafe Siege, Inquest Is Told
item.description: One of the two hostages who died during a 17-hour siege of a downtown Sydney cafe in December “was struck by six fragments of a police bullet or bullets, which ricocheted from hard surfaces into her body.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Former Top Venezuela Aide Said to Flee Amid Inquiry
item.description: Venezuelan leaders respond to reports that an ex-chief of the security for the National Assembly leader has implicated him as a drug trafficker.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: 2 Sentenced in Murders in Chile Coup
item.description: A ruling said the murders of two Americans were the result of a “secret investigation” of Americans’ political activities in Chile by the United States Military Group in Santiago.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Party Paper Reports on Meeting of Fidel Castro and Brazilian Author
item.description: Cuba’s former leader Fidel Castro met with Frei Betto, a Brazilian intellectual, this week, the first such meeting reported in the state-run Cuban news media since a recent swell of rumors that he was dead.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Washington Post Reporter’s Trial to Be ‘Soon,’ but Charges Are Unclear
item.description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated since July 22, “will be tried soon,” Iran’s state-run Islamic Republic News Agency said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Drastic Water Rationing May Be Put in Place in São Paulo
item.description: The worst drought to hit São Paulo, Brazil’s biggest city, in decades may leave many residents with water service only two days a week.
item.category: Companhia de Saneamento Basico do Estado de Sao Paulo
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Canada Agency Monitors File-Sharing, Reports Say
item.description: A document leaked by Edward J. Snowden outlines an effort by the Canadian electronic spying agency to detect possible extremists; some privacy experts expressed concerns.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Iran Bows to Pressure in Naming U.N. Envoy
item.description: An announcement of the appointment came nine months after the United States had made clear that Iran’s first choice, Hamid Aboutalebi, would never get a visa.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Administration Official Criticizes Israeli Ambassador Over Netanyahu Visit
item.description: The tension with Israel is over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s acceptance of Republican leaders’ invitation to address Congress about Iran without consulting the White House.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Ron Dermer, Israel’s ambassador to the United States. He said he did not intend to anger the White House over the speech.

item.title: Xu Shilin, a Young Chinese Player, Tries to Step Into the Void Left by Li Na
item.description: Xu, 17, was the first Chinese player to be seeded No. 1 in a Grand Slam singles event when she got the top spot in the junior girls’ draw at the Australian Open.
item.dc:creator: By BEN ROTHENBERG
item.media:description: Xu Shilin has continued to develop into an elite player, with her best results coming last fall.

item.title: Ukraine Clamps Down on Travel to and From Rebel Areas
item.description: After new border restrictions were put in place, a policy of isolating and frustrating rebel-held regions has taken a major and maddening turn.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting in Velikaya Novoselka, Ukraine, to apply for permits to cross the front line.
